meaning_mnemonic: If you stab somebody in the <radical>tongue</radical> with an <radical>umbrella</radical>, it’s sure to start a <kanji>riot</kanji> and cause <kanji>disorder</kanji>. Nobody likes to get stabbed in the tongue with an umbrella, so they’re probably going to retaliate, and before you know it, you’ve a full scale riot on your hands. Look what you’ve done.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself getting stabbed in the tongue with an umbrella. It’s very painful. Taste the blood and metal in your mouth as this happens to you.
reading_mnemonic: Just now you realize that the man you stabbed in the tongue with your umbrella was none other than Macho Man <reading>Ran</reading>dy Savage (らん). Being a professional wrestler, Macho Man Randy Savage is ready to throw down at a moment’s notice. A <kanji>riot</kanji> immediately erupts. It’s a battle royal with you and Randy at the epicenter.
reading_hint: Picture yourself squaring off with Macho Man Randy Savage in the middle of this riot. You have the advantage of having an umbrella, but Randy has the advantage of being himself. Picture yourself getting into a fight with him.

meaning_mnemonic: You use a <radical>bookshelf</radical> as a <kanji>book counter</kanji>. Duh. What, are you gonna count them one by one? Okay, well maybe, but you should count them while they're nice and organized on the shelves. Otherwise counting is going to be a huge pain.
meaning_hint: Imagine counting books on a bunch of bookshelves. One book, two book, red book, blue book!
reading_mnemonic: You use this <kanji>book counter</kanji> method to count all the books <reading>Satsu</reading>ki (さつ) has in her house. Remember her? She's got, like, a ton of books, but she's just a little girl so she needs some help. That's where your book counter know-how comes in handy.
reading_hint: Imagine how tedious it'd be to watch her counting one by one. Teach her your book counter ways!

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>mouth</radical> has the <radical>power</radical> to <kanji>add</kanji> words together to form a sentence. Marvel at the massive and mighty power your mouth holds! You add words together in an amazing fashion!
meaning_hint: Say this sentence out loud. Incredible! You’ve used the power of your mouth to add words together in a sentence. Your parents must be very proud of you.
reading_mnemonic: Your parents are so proud of you for using your powerful mouth to <kanji>add</kanji> words together that they decide to surprise you with a gift. It’s a new <reading>ca</reading>r (か). It’s that shiny brand new car that you’d always wanted. You’re speechless. However, your speechlessness frustrates your parents so they decide to take away the car they just gave you. Boo hoo.
reading_hint: Imagine how awful it would be to have a new car given to you only to have it taken away immediately after. Feel this rollercoaster of emotion as you are joyful and excited, then sad and sorrowful.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>history</radical> radical and the <kanji>history</kanji> kanji are the same.
meaning_hint: Know your radicals, yo!
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>History</kanji> was full of famous <reading>shee</reading>p (し). Sure there are people and stuff, but historical sheep are where it's at. There's the famous sheep samurai, the death sheep who works for the yakuza, just tons!
reading_hint: Look at a history book, behind each of those humans was a sheep, changing the world as we know it.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>sheep</radical> loses its <radical>horns</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical> so it picks them up in its <radical>mouth</radical> to take them to someone who's <kanji>morally good</kanji> enough to attach them back onto its head. Sheep don’t have hands, so the sheep had to pick the horns up off the ground with his mouth. Someone evil would just murder the sheep and steal his horns, so the sheep must find someone <kanji>good</kanji> to reaffix them.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself as the good person being approached by this forlorn sheep without horns. Hear the clack of the horns together as the sheep drops them out of his mouth onto the ground and lets out a pathetic bleat. “Baa~aa~ah~”
reading_mnemonic: Since you are <kanji>morally good</kanji>, you decide not to murder the sheep and harvest its organs. Instead, as a practitioner of the <kanji>good</kanji> teachings of <reading>Zen</reading> (ぜん) Buddhism, you decided to help the sheep out. Your Zen teachings have increased the power of your healing abilities, so you fix the sheep up in no time.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself using your Zen magic to heal this sheep. Place your hands on the sheep’s horns and imagine returning them to their rightful location on the sheep’s head. Feel the soft wool of the sheep as he bleats in happiness.

meaning_mnemonic: Use your <radical>mouth</radical> to take a <radical>measurement</radical> of this <kanji>group</kanji>. Just stretch your mouth out and around every single person. Get 'em all in there.
meaning_hint: I hope this group is full of people who enjoy being inside someone else's mouth, because they're gonna be pretty mad when you let them out if they aren't.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>group</kanji> is so big it takes you till <reading>dawn</reading> (だん) to get your measurement: they weigh a <reading>ton</reading> (とん) too!
reading_hint: Imagine letting this group of, now very wet, people out of your mouth one by one. They don't seem to care that they weigh a ton! That's a large measurement, they should be proud.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>dirt</radical> next to your <radical>village</radical> is where you <kanji>bury</kanji> the dead. People don't live forever, so every village has a patch of dirt specifically used for burying dead things.
meaning_hint: Imagine the village where you grew up. Can you see the dirt area where all your ancestors were buried?
reading_mnemonic: You don't just <kanji>bury</kanji> dead relatives here. You also buried your dead pet <reading>u</reading>ni (う) in that dirt. You thought having an uni as a pet would be a good idea. Too bad uni need water to survive.
reading_hint: Imagine crying as you bury your pet uni. Your tears can't save it now. (Though it is a bit ironic, since it needed salt water.)

meaning_mnemonic: You use a <radical>roof</radical> to keep yourself <radical>dry</radical> and safe from <kanji>outer space</kanji>. Look outside, above your roof, and you'll see outer space stretching above you.
meaning_hint: You don't want to float up into outer space and get all wet, do you? No? Then you better make sure you have a roof above your head.
reading_mnemonic: Why isn't it dry in <kanji>outer space</kanji>, you ask? Because of all the <reading>u</reading>ni (う) swimming around up there. They have nasty, wet, pointy spikes and they're all over the place.
reading_hint: Look closely up at outer space and you'll see all of the uni floating around up there. They're really dark, so it can be hard to notice them, but I promise you, they're there.

meaning_mnemonic: You jumped off your <radical>roof</radical> for some <radical>reason</radical> and now you're floating in <kanji>midair</kanji>! You kick your legs a bit and move your arms like you're in water, but you're still just stuck there in midair.
meaning_hint: At the moment you can't remember the reason you did it, but when you jumped off your roof you just floated in midair.
reading_mnemonic: As you spin a bit in <kanji>midair</kanji> you look up and see <reading>Chew</reading>bacca (ちゅう) looking down at you from a spaceship. He's laughing his Chewbacca laugh and you realize he has you trapped in his tractor beam.
reading_hint: Oh Chewbacca, you lovable fuzzball. You better not drop me in midair, or I'll die. I hope you bring me up there!

meaning_mnemonic: If you put a <radical>roof</radical> over a <radical>valley</radical> it will change its <kanji>form</kanji>. Its <kanji>appearance</kanji> will alter completely!
meaning_hint: Picture a valley in your mind. Now put a roof on it. Hmm. It isn't <kanji>shape</kanji>d like a valley anymore.
reading_mnemonic: Its new <kanji>appearance</kanji> looks familiar to you, like it's a big <reading>yo</reading>gurt (よう) cup! A valley with a roof on it looks exactly like a yogurt cup. Huh!
reading_hint: Now imagine this taking shape before your eyes and becoming actual yogurt! You grab a giant spoon and take a bite.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>flag</radical> <radical>loiter</radical>s in a <radical>black hole</radical>. This flag marks (in the black hole) where you left your <kanji>footwear</kanji>.
meaning_hint: If you look into the black hole, you can see your footwear right there, marked with the flag.
reading_mnemonic: You grab your <kanji>footwear</kanji> from the black hole. In your footwear (thanks to the shelter they provided), some <reading>ree</reading>ds (り) have grown in!
reading_hint: It's amazing that these cute little reeds could grow in your footwear in the middle of a black hole. As a great philosopher once said, life finds a way.

meaning_mnemonic: To a <radical>narwhal</radical>, a <radical>towel</radical> is just normal <kanji>cloth</kanji>. They're always wet so towel cloth is all they know.
meaning_hint: Picture a narwhal wrapped in a fuzzy towel blanket, with a towel tail cover, and some towel underpants. Everything is made of this type of cloth.
reading_mnemonic: If you use this type of <kanji>cloth</kanji> for your clothes and blankets people will call you a <reading>foo</reading>l (ふ). They think you're a fool who can't tell the difference between human cloth and towel cloth.
reading_hint: "You fool, you aren't a narwhal, that cloth isn't for you!" they say. They're so mean.

meaning_mnemonic: “Don’t <radical>loiter</radical> – <radical>run</radical>, <kanji>Junior</kanji>!” said Indiana Jones Senior to Indiana Jones Junior. They’re escaping from a sticky situation and Junior was just loitering around like a fool. It’s no time to loiter, it’s time to run!
meaning_hint: Imagine Sean Connery saying “Don’t loiter – run, Junior!” and you should have a much easier time remembering this phrase if you remember it in his voice.
reading_mnemonic: Deciding not to loiter any longer, Indiana Jones <kanji>Junior</kanji> takes his dad’s advice and starts to run. Unfortunately he wasn’t paying attention to where his feet were and he stubbed his <reading>to</reading>e (と) on a jagged rock. His toe is in so much pain that he can’t bear to run any longer.
reading_hint: Imagine that you are Indiana Jones Junior and this is happening to you. Feel the terrible pain of your throbbing toe as you clutch it, with the bad guys catching up with you.

meaning_mnemonic: If you <radical>loiter</radical> around the <radical>sun</radical> <radical>temple</radical>, it's likely you'll <kanji>acquire</kanji> something. When you loiter around like that it looks like you're waiting for something, so if someone puts something in your hands and you just happen to acquire it, well, no one can fault you for that.
meaning_hint: Imagine loitering around near the sun temple. Maybe you acquire some illegal goods, maybe you just acquire a tan (it is a SUN temple, after all).
reading_mnemonic: You managed to <kanji>acquire</kanji> some tobacco, but just as you're about to leave <reading>Toku</reading>gawa (とく) Ieyasu comes marching up to you!! Or at least, his ghost does. He stares you dead in the eyes and says, "I didn't found the shogunate for you to acquire illegal goods and kill your body toking on my soil."
reading_hint: Your eyes fill with tears under Tokugawa's gaze and you drop everything you acquired to the ground. You bow before him apologizing. You'll never do this again!

meaning_mnemonic: You'll work your <radical>soul</radical> to <radical>death</radical> if you're too <kanji>busy</kanji>. Being busy just isn't good for your soul. Take breaks. Go on vacation. Don't be so busy that you destroy yourself.
meaning_hint: Look around you. See all those busy people? Their souls are dying. Don't end up like them.
reading_mnemonic: Take time out of your <kanji>busy</kanji> life and go <reading>bow</reading>ling (ぼう) once in a while. In fact, you should probably go bowling once a week at least. Nothing brings energy back to your life like some relaxing bowling.
reading_hint: Think about your busy schedule this week. Now cancel everything and just go bowling instead.

meaning_mnemonic: It's important to focus <radical>oneself</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> so that one can emerge <kanji>renew</kanji>ed! You can't really go outside in winter without getting cold or sick, so spend winter focusing on YOU.
meaning_hint: Imagine sitting in your house all winter, meditating and thinking about how you can renew yourself.
reading_mnemonic: Winter ends and, <kanji>renew</kanji>ed, you come out ready to start a new hobby: <reading>kay</reading>aking (かい)! Nothing says renewal like a brand new kayak and sense of purpose in life.
reading_hint: Imagine being back in your house in winter. You're thinking about all the kayaking you're gonna do when winter ends. You're even making the movements with your arms, so you'll be a really renewed you.

meaning_mnemonic: If the <radical>sun</radical> is <radical>compare</radical>d to an <kanji>insect</kanji>, you’ll see that they're both shiny, but that the sun is much shinier than the insect.
meaning_hint: Imagine holding up an insect to the sun to compare the two. See how they both shine, but the sun shines more brightly than the insect.
reading_mnemonic: While you’re holding up an <kanji>insect</kanji> to the sun for comparison, a flock of <reading>con</reading>dors (こん) flies by, blocking out the sun. There are so many condors that they manage to totally block out the sun.
reading_hint: Feel how dark and cold it is suddenly with all those condors blocking out the sun.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>easy</radical> radical and the <kanji>easy</kanji> kanji are the same!
meaning_hint: Easy is easy!
reading_mnemonic: What would be an <kanji>easy</kanji> reading for this kanji? <reading>い</reading>! The sound easy starts with!
reading_hint: I told you easy was easy.

meaning_mnemonic: When the <radical>sun</radical> gets <radical>together</radical> with <radical>water</radical>, only <kanji>violence</kanji> can ensue. They don’t mix well together. The sun loves to fight water and water loves to fight the sun. Lots and lots of violence.
meaning_hint: Picture this violent fight scene in your brain. Imagine water locked in battle with the sun as the sun’s fire flares up and the water starts to sizzle.
reading_mnemonic: But after a while, the sun and the water have had enough of <kanji>violence</kanji>. They decide to settle their differences with a friendly game of <reading>bow</reading>ling (ぼう). Bowling is a great way to relieve stress and in the end, they bond over it.
reading_hint: Imagine the sun and the water trying to bowl. Hear the sound of bowling balls rolling down the lane and pins rattling around and crashing together.

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>stop</radical> at a <radical>cliff</radical> with a <radical>tree</radical> on it, realizing that <kanji>continuation</kanji> is impossible unless you find some way to bridge the gap to the other side of the cliff. The tree seems long enough to reach to the other side, but how are you going to chop it down?
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself on this cliff. You desire a continuation for your journey, not wanting to stop here. Feel the strong wind on your body, blowing your hair about as you stand on the edge of the cliff. The leaves on the tree rustle in the breeze.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Continuation</kanji> is impossible unless you chop this tree down to use as a bridge to cross to the other side of the cliff. You decide to use a <reading>wrecki</reading>ng (れき) ball. Luckily, there’s one right by you. So you take the wrecking ball and knock the tree over, making a bridge with it.
reading_hint: Picture yourself using the wrecking ball to knock down the tree on the cliff. Hear the chug of the wrecking ball engine as the tree cracks and splinters from the force of the wrecking ball.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Compare</radical> the <radical>sun</radical> with a <radical>tsunami</radical> – these two things don’t <kanji>mix</kanji>. If a tsunami is coming, it will likely get in the way of the sun.
meaning_hint: Imagine the sun getting blocked out as a tsunami rises up from the ocean. Feel the cold fear of death on you as the tsunami approaches. That tsunami is gonna mix you up.
reading_mnemonic: Just before the tsunami crashes over you, a <reading>con</reading>dor (こん) swoops out of the sky and grabs you up. This condor must be a <kanji>mix</kanji> – a normal condor is not strong enough to pick up a human. The condor must be mixed with something else. Like a pterodactyl.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself getting mixed up in this situation and the pterodactyl sized condor picking you up. Feel the condor’s talons digging into your shoulders as it grabs you up and flies you towards the sun.

meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>tsunami</radical> coming, but the escape <radical>slide</radical> is being blocked by a <radical>drunkard</radical> and <radical>creeper</radical>, and you can see your chances of escaping <kanji>decrease</kanji> rapidly.
meaning_hint: Imagine how you feel as you try to get down the tsunami slide, past the drunkard and the creeper, who are decreasing your chances of getting away.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>decrease</kanji> in the chances of escaping the tsunami is really upsetting <reading>Gen</reading>ji (げん), who's waiting impatiently behind you.
reading_hint: Picture Genji, as his chances of survival decrease along with yours. Poor Genji.

meaning_mnemonic: Is there a <radical>reason</radical> you're in the <radical>bamboo</radical> grove? Why yes there is. It's so you can get yourself some bamboo and make a <kanji>flute</kanji> out of it.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself cutting down some bamboo, thinking "this is the reason I'm here, I need a flute, asap!" There is no other reason to be here besides this.
reading_mnemonic: You cut down the bamboo and whittle a <kanji>flute</kanji>. You start playing a song. You know the reason why. An alien spacecraft comes flying down and drops a box full of alien <reading>tech</reading> (てき) in front of you.
reading_hint: You've done what you came to do. You summoned an alien craft with your bamboo flute, gaining some alien tech in the process. Open up the box to see what tech awaits you.

meaning_mnemonic:
On the bottom of <radical>bamboo</radical> <radical>root</radical>s, there’s a <radical>stamp</radical> that tells you the <kanji>season</kanji> in which it was cut.

Additionally, the stamp also has information on the condition of the bamboo’s <kanji>joint</kanji>s, because no one wants to buy bamboo with damaged joints!
meaning_hint: Picture yourself in a store, looking at a bunch of different bamboo stamps to make sure you don’t buy one that’s out of season, or one that has damaged joints. The season and the joints, that’s what quality bamboo is all about, and it’s why we have these stamps!
reading_mnemonic: These <kanji>season</kanji> stamps are marked on bamboo <reading>sets</reading> (せつ). You can't buy a single banana or a single grape, and just like that, if you want some nice seasonal bamboo, you have to buy them in sets.
reading_hint: How many bamboo sets will you be buying this season? I'm getting 42 sets.

meaning_mnemonic: If you put a <radical>thread</radical> in the middle of a <radical>kiss</radical>, you’re going to <kanji>entangle</kanji> it. Things can get pretty messy in a kiss, so adding a thread to the mix will definitely entangle it.
meaning_hint: Imagine trying to kiss someone with a piece of thread between your lips. Feel the thread getting all entangled between the two of you as you lock lips. It’s really detracting from the experience.
reading_mnemonic: This is your first kiss ever so getting a thread to <kanji>entangle</kanji> between your lips was really bad <reading>luck</reading> (らく). The person you were trying to kiss got really grossed out by the thread and tried to push you away but was so entangled with the thread that they were unable. Bad luck indeed.
reading_hint: Picture yourself being tied to someone by the tongue with thread. You can’t escape, and you can’t believe your bad luck. Feel the thread tugging on your tongue as you try to get yourself untangled.

meaning_mnemonic: You have to <radical>sell</radical> <radical>thread</radical> if you want to <kanji>continue</kanji> to live. You want to make a living don’t you? Make sure you continue to sell that thread every single day!
meaning_hint: Imagine selling thread so you can continue living your life.
reading_mnemonic: You have to <kanji>continue</kanji> to sell that thread because a Boso<reading>zoku</reading> (ぞく) bike gang is forcing you to do it. You see? If you want to continue to live, you have to appease this Bosozoku gang. You better keep selling!
reading_hint: Continue selling thread and paying off the Bosozoku. It’s the only way you can continue to survive!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>tongue</radical> radical and the <kanji>tongue</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Yee-haw!
reading_mnemonic: You’re sound asleep in bed when your <kanji>tongue</kanji> drops out of your mouth and you start to drool, getting saliva all over the bed <reading>sheet</reading> (した). You wake up with a soggy patch of sheet near your mouth and wipe the drool off your face. Your significant other sees the whole thing.
reading_hint: Your significant other had been watching you sleep with your tongue out for a while now, so you're super embarrassed you wet the sheets with your nasty tongue drool. You feel very judged and embarrassed.

meaning_mnemonic: If you see some <radical>flowers</radical> that are <radical>dry</radical>, pull them up and you'll find a <kanji>potato</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Potatoes grow when flowers dry out. All the nutrients are going to the potato under the ground, so the flowers up top get sucked dry.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Potato</kanji>es are totally <reading>emo</reading> (いも) because of the way they dry out flowers. Emo people and potatoes both like to dry out flowers.
reading_hint: Picture an emo person sitting alone in a dark room, staring at a potato. "You and I are the same."

meaning_mnemonic: There are <radical>flowers</radical> on your <radical>right</radical> to show that you're still <kanji>young</kanji>. Your body still works, you're happy, you have your entire life ahead of you! And everything smells like flowers.
meaning_hint: Look to your right, if you see flowers (metaphorically, maybe) then you're still young. Congratulations!
reading_mnemonic: When <kanji>young</kanji> people look to the right, they'll see their future: a <reading>walke</reading>r (わか). You know, those metal contraptions with tennis balls on the bottoms to make sure they don't scrape the floor. Everything may be flowers and happiness now, but your future is in a walker.
reading_hint: All young people have a walker looming just off to the side. A sign that your youth won't last forever, dear summer child.

meaning_mnemonic: What you <radical>say</radical> to the <radical>director</radical> is judged immediately. You're having trouble understanding this <kanji>part of speech</kanji>, so he's trying to help you. But you say it over and over and he keeps saying you're wrong.
meaning_hint:
"Is it an adjective?"
"No, that's the wrong part of speech."
"Is it a verb?"
"N-no! Of course not!"
reading_mnemonic: The director asks you again, "What is the part of speech for the word <reading>shee</reading>p (し)?"
reading_hint: You stare blankly at him. What part of speech is that?! It's an animal, you know that. Oh! A noun. Duh.

meaning_mnemonic: Give some <radical>shellfish</radical> to a <radical>talent</radical>ed person and they'll have no problem accumulating <kanji>wealth</kanji>. People with talent can make money out of pretty much anything, so shellfish are like easy-mode.
meaning_hint: Picture the talented person huddled over a pile of shellfish, whispering to them about the wealth they'll soon be turned into.
reading_mnemonic: This talented person really starts accumulating <kanji>wealth</kanji> when their <reading>cy</reading>borg (さい) is unveiled. It's a half-man, half-shellfish cyborg that plays the <reading>xy</reading>lophone , and everyone wants to buy it.
reading_hint: You'd be wealthy too if you sold that cyborg you made. It may not have any shellfish in it and it can't play the xylophone, but you could change that…

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>scooter</radical> and your <radical>car</radical> is what you always <kanji>take along</kanji> with you. Make sure they're <kanji>connect</kanji>ed well so you don't lose them!
meaning_hint: Your scooter and your car, connected by a tiny little string, are the two things you take along with you wherever you go.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>take along</kanji> your scooter and your car. Anything else, you can do a <reading>ren</reading>tal (れん) for!
reading_hint: The roof over your head? Rental. The clothes on your body? Rental. All of your friends? Rental. The only thing you permanently take along with you are your scooter and your car.

meaning_mnemonic: Passed out in front of the <radical>gate</radical> lies a <radical>drunkard</radical> who used to be the <radical>leader</radical> of a popular <kanji>clique</kanji>, the Cool Kids <kanji>Clan</kanji>. Once, he was a leader, but now he is but a drunkard. The clan has fallen apart, and he no longer has a clique to call his own.
meaning_hint: Imagine this washed up drunkard leader passed out in front of the gate to your house. You have to pass him whenever you enter or exit your house. He’s gross and he smells. Experience the stench in your nostrils. How he was ever the leader of a clan you have no idea.
reading_mnemonic: Eventually you get sick and tired of this washed up <kanji>clan</kanji> leader and you gather your own <kanji>clique</kanji> to chase this guy away from your gate and your property. You and your friends grab some <reading>bats</reading> (ばつ) and use these bats to beat the drunkard leader. Being beaten with bats frightens him, and he scurries away.
reading_hint: Hear the crushing blows of bats against flesh as you imagine this scene in your mind. You’re beating the crap out of this guy with a bunch of bats, but hey – he had it coming.

meaning_mnemonic: For a <radical>geoduck</radical> to make it into a <radical>river</radical>, it must know the <kanji>sequence</kanji> and <kanji>order</kanji> of water flow. Geoducks usually live in the ocean, not in a river, so they must study the order of water flow in order to determine the best sequence for making it into a river.
meaning_hint: Imagine this geoduck mapping out a plan to get to the river. It’s studying the sequence and order of water flow. See it sitting there, reading a book, reading glasses and all. It’s quite odd.
reading_mnemonic: After extensive study of the <kanji>sequence</kanji> and <kanji>order</kanji> of water, the geoduck has determined that <reading>June</reading> (じゅん) is the best time to travel to the river. June is the best time for the temperature and atmospheric pressure to be just right for such a journey. In June, the geoduck will set out.
reading_hint: June has arrived. Imagine the geoduck making its way from the ocean to the river. Use whatever makes you think of June to link that month to this scene of the geoduck making his way to the river.
